extracted_metadata.title: The Uncanny
extracted_metadata.author: Sigmund Freud
extracted_metadata.subject: Psychoanalysis and Aesthetics
extracted_metadata.summary: The Uncanny discusses the intersection between psychoanalysis and aesthetics, particularly focusing on the emotional responses evoked by feelings of fear and dread. Freud explores the concept of the 'uncanny' and its relation to aesthetics, addressing the limited scholarly attention this topic has received. The text serves as an investigation into the emotional impulses associated with unsettling experiences.

text_sample:
2003

Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Penguin Classics, 1998), and co-edited, with Adam Phillips, John Clare in Context (1994). His study of the poetry of Derek Mahon is due to be published in 2004.

ADAM PHILLIPS was formerly Principal Child Psychotherapist at Charing Cross Hospital in London. He is the author of several books on psychoanalysis including On Kissing, Tickling and Being Bored, Darwin's Worms, Promises, Promises and Houdini's Box.

Translated by DAVID MCLINTOCK with an I
